Introduction
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the most noble of Prophets and Messengers. To proceed:
Indeed, among Allah's blessings upon His servants is that He sent His Prophet to them with the tolerant Hanifiyyah (monotheism), and He made ease one of the characteristics of this final message. He said: {Those who follow the Messenger, the unlettered prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. So they who have believed in him, honored him, supported him and followed the light which was sent down with him - it is those who will be the successful.} [Al-A'raf: 157].
This verse has outlined the features of this eternal message through the description of His Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, and stated that he was sent to remove burdens and shackles. It is a depiction of the state of distress and hardship that this Sharia has removed through tolerance and ease.

Al-Isr (burden) is described by al-Nadheer ibn Shumail as: the heavy covenant. Every heavy thing is an isr, because it binds its owner, meaning it restricts him from movement. Al-Aghlāl (chains) — plural of ghil, with a ḍammah — are iron fetters that are placed around the neck and hands. Murtada, in his book 'Al-Tāj', says about al-aghlāl: 'They are repeatedly mentioned in the Qur’an and Sunnah, and refer to difficult obligations and demanding acts, not to facilitation.'

Facilitation and the removal of hardship is not merely a juristic principle, expressed by the jurists with sayings like: “Hardship brings ease,” and Imam al-Shāfi‘ī’s statement: “When a matter becomes tight, it is made wide.” Rather, facilitation and removal of hardship are objectives of the higher purposes of Shariah. The Qur’an and Sunnah explicitly indicate this in several places. Allah, the Exalted, says: {Allah does not burden any soul beyond its capacity. It will have the reward of what it earns, and it will bear the consequences of what it does. Our Lord, do not punish us if we forget or make mistakes. Our Lord, do not place upon us a burden like that which You placed upon those before us. Our Lord, do not impose upon us that which we have no strength to bear.} [Al-Baqarah: 286].

text: And it was stated in the Musnad (1) from the Hadith of Abu Umamah in a Marfu' narration: 'I was not sent with Judaism or Christianity, but I was sent with the tolerant Hanifiyyah (Monotheism).' Al-Bukhari reported (2) from the Hadith of Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, who said: 'The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, was never given a choice between two matters but that he chose the easier of the two, as long as it was not a sin. If it was a sin, he was the furthest of people from it.' She only said: 'as long as it was not a sin' because there is no hardship in avoiding sin. The legitimacy of definitively established concessions, such as shortening prayers for the traveler combined with joining them, and consuming forbidden things in cases of necessity, is nothing but definitive proof of the absolute removal of difficulty and hardship. If the aforementioned legal texts came to establish the rule of facilitation and the removal of hardship in matters of religion in general, then the intent of facilitation appears in Hajj specifically. text: Al-Aas, that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood at the Farewell Pilgrimage in Mina for the people to ask him questions. A man came to him and said: 'I did not realize, so I shaved before I slaughtered.' He said: 'Slaughter, and there is no harm.' Another came and said: 'I did not realize, so I slaughtered before I threw [the pebbles].' He said: 'Throw, and there is no harm.' The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was not asked about anything done before or after [its order] except that he said: 'Do it, and there is no harm.' Since Hajj is an act of worship explicitly linked to capability, and Hajj in many of its rulings is based on choice, and choice is the foundation of facilitation, this is a general ruling for all pilgrims. So how much more so for women, for whom the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counted Hajj as Jihad? He said in what was reported by Imam Ahmad (1) and Ibn Majah (2) from the Hadith of Aisha, who said: I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, is there Jihad upon women?' He said: 'Yes, upon them is a Jihad in which there is no fighting: Hajj and Umrah.' The wording is Ahmad's, and Al-Albani authenticated it in Al-Irwa (3). And in Al-Bukhari in the Chapter of Women's Hajj (4) from the Hadith of Aisha, she said:

text: I said: 'O Messenger of Allah, shall we not go on expeditions and fight [Jihad] with you?' He said: 'But the best and most beautiful Jihad is Hajj: an accepted Hajj (Hajj Mabrur).' Aisha said: 'So I will not leave Hajj after hearing this from the Messenger of Allah.' Indeed, Hajj is the Jihad of every weak person, as reported by Ibn Majah (1) from the Hadith of Umm Salamah who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Hajj is the Jihad of every weak person.' Al-Albani graded it Hasan. And in Al-Nasa'i (2) with a chain that has no harm (La ba'sa bihi) from the Hadith of Abu Huraira in a Marfu' narration: 'The Jihad of the elderly, the young, the weak, and the woman is Hajj and Umrah.' There is no doubt that the choice of the word 'Jihad' by the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, has its significance and meanings. 'Jihad' is a state in which the exertion of effort and the occurrence of hardship are visualized. It is a word that serves as a premise for results regarding forms of facilitation and mitigation for those in this state, as you will see, God willing. In the research, the approach to dealing with hardships in Hajj will become clear to you, especially with the existence of ongoing disagreement and the absence of definitive text.

text: Ibn al-Qayyim says regarding the change of times, places, and conditions: 'This is a chapter of very great benefit. Due to ignorance of it, a great error has occurred against the Sharia, necessitating difficulty, hardship, and the imposition of what is impossible, which it is known that the magnificent Sharia, which is at the highest levels of welfare, would not bring. For the Sharia is built and founded upon wisdom and the welfare of the servants in their livelihood and their afterlife. It is all justice, all mercy, all benefit, and all wisdom. So every issue that departs from justice to injustice, from mercy to its opposite, from benefit to corruption, and from wisdom to futility, is not from the Sharia, even if it is entered into it by interpretation. The Sharia is Allah's justice among His servants, His mercy among His creation, and His wisdom pointing to Him and to the truthfulness of His Messenger' (1). The change of time referred to is the change in people's conditions; pilgrims who used to be counted in thousands are now counted in millions, and the few souls that used to die during the Hajj season are now counted in hundreds. The point is that maintaining rulings on minor details that contradict the objectives of the Sharia, leading to hardship and distress, is contrary to the spirit of the Sharia and is a mistake.

text: Chapter One: Manifestations of Facilitation Before Hajj. Topic One: The Capability That Makes Hajj Obligatory for the Afaqi. There is no doubt that the obligation of Hajj has conditions according to scholars; some are conditions for obligation and validity, some are conditions for obligation and fulfillment, and some are conditions for obligation only. The Imams have elaborated on these in their books. In this issue, I will discuss one of the conditions of obligation, which is capability (Istita'ah), as it contains the first manifestation of Allah's facilitation for His servants in Hajj. There is no disagreement among scholars that capability is a condition for the obligation of Hajj (1), due to His saying: {In it are clear signs [such as] the standing place of Abraham. And whoever enters it shall be safe. And [due] to Allah from the people is a pilgrimage to the House - for whoever is able to find thereto a way. But whoever disbelieves - then indeed, Allah is free from need of the worlds.} [Al Imran: 97]. However, scholars differed in defining the reality of this capability and its conditions, noting that capability is of two types:

text: Physical capability (by oneself), and capability through others. What concerns us in this issue is the first type, which is physical capability for the Afaqi (one living outside the Miqat boundaries) who has a distance between them and Mecca that qualifies as travel. Scholars have mentioned conditions to clarify the reality of capability; some are common to both men and women, and others are specific to women. I will detail what is specific to women. Among the conditions shared by men and women in defining the reality of capability are: 1. Health of the body, such that one is not sick and unable to stay stable on the mount (1). 2. Safety of the road, such that safety is the prevailing assumption (2). 3. Availability of necessary provisions. 4. Availability of a mount (transportation), either by ownership or by rental (3).

text: As for the condition specific to women: The presence of a Mahram. A woman's Mahram is her husband or someone she is permanently forbidden to marry. Scholars have differed regarding this condition with several opinions, the most famous of which are: The First Opinion: Hajj is not obligatory for a woman who has no Mahram. This was stated by Al-Hasan, Al-Nakha'i, the Hanafis, the Hanbalis in their school, Ishaq, Ibn Al-Mundhir, and Al-Baghawi (1). They used the following as evidence: What Al-Bukhari (2) and Muslim (3) reported from the Hadith of Abu Huraira, who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'It is not lawful for a woman who believes in Allah and the Last Day to travel a distance of a day and a night unless she has a Mahram with her.' The wording is Muslim's. Scholars interpreted this Hadith according to its general meaning; because 'a woman' (imra'ah) in the Hadith is indefinite in the context of negation, so it implies generality. Accordingly, Al-Nawawi titled a chapter in his explanation of Sahih Muslim: 'Chapter: A Woman's Travel with a Mahram for Hajj and Other Purposes.'

He said: 'O Adi, have you seen Al-Hirah?' I said: 'I have not seen it, but I have been informed about it.' He said: 'If you live long enough, you will see a woman traveling in a litter (Dha'inah) from Al-Hirah until she circumambulates the Kaaba, fearing no one but Allah...'. The point of evidence is that it is a report in the context of praise and the elevation of Islam, so it is interpreted as permissibility (2). It was answered: Not everything the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, foretold would happen implies prohibition or permissibility, because he stated its occurrence, not its permissibility. And since mere reporting of the unseen does not imply permissibility, how can obligation be derived from it? According to those who say it is obligatory when company is available (3). 2. text: from traveling except with their Mahrams. Considering the evidence and instructions presented, it appears—and Allah knows best—that Hajj is not obligatory for a woman unless there is a husband or Mahram, for the following reasons: 1. The Hadiths used by the majority are authentic and explicit, and there is nothing contradicting them. Ibn Al-Mundhir said: 'They abandoned the apparent meaning of the Hadith, and each of them stipulated a condition for which he has no proof' (1). 2. The Hadith of Adi bin Hatim, may Allah be pleased with him, used by the proponents of the second opinion, indicates she travels alone, yet they stipulated the company of men and women, so they did not follow their own evidence nor the evidence of the first opinion. Topic Two: Permission of the Husband for the Woman in the Obligatory Hajj. If the Hajj is voluntary, scholars do not differ that a woman may not enter Ihram without her husband's permission. If she enters Ihram without his permission, he is permitted to make her exit Ihram if he wishes. Consensus on this has been reported (2).

text: However, if the Hajj is obligatory (Fard), there are two opinions regarding the ruling on a husband preventing his wife from Ihram: The First Opinion: The husband does not have the right to prevent his wife from proceeding to the obligatory Hajj if the conditions of obligation are met. This is the view held by the Hanafis (1), the Hanbalis (2), the Shafi'is in a less preferred view (3), and Ibn Hazm (4). The Malikis have two views based on the opinion regarding the immediacy of Hajj. Some said: Hajj is obligatory immediately (Ala al-Fawr), chosen by Qadi Abd al-Wahhab (5), and based on this, the husband has no right to prevent her. Others said: Hajj is obligatory with delay allowed (Ala al-Tarakhi), chosen by Al-Qurtubi. They said: If she is not prevented from the mosque for prayer, she should not be prevented from intending the Sanctuary for Hajj. The Hadith was answered by saying it is interpreted as a prohibition of dislike (Tanzihi) or applied to unmarried women; because unmarried women do not have an immediate right attached to them [by a husband], such as a daughter or sister and the like, and that the meaning is 'do not prevent them from the mosques of Allah for prayers' (2) (3). 2. That Hajj is obligatory, and he has no right to prevent her from obligations, just as he has no right to prevent her from prayer and fasting. The Shafi'is answered that the duration of Hajj is long, unlike fasting and prayer. The Second Opinion: The husband may prevent his wife from going out for the obligatory Hajj.

The third category of voluntary acts does not relate to the person alone but relates to others due to crowding in the place or otherwise. Hajj is of the third category, for the ritual sites are limited and the time is narrow. The point of evidence from it is: consideration is given to the generality of the wording, not the specificity of the cause. So if the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, directs a ruling to a person, it is general for that person and for the Ummah; because it is not possible for the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, to address every person individually. If he addresses one of the Ummah with a legal ruling, the rest of the Ummah shares in that ruling. Also, the pilgrim performing Hajj or Umrah is not safe from an excuse befalling them. text: They used the following as evidence: First: The aforementioned Hadith of Urwa bin Mudarris. The point of evidence: 'and stood before that at Arafat by night or day, then his Hajj is complete, and he has completed his prescribed duties' indicates the sufficiency of standing for one who stood during the day and then departed before sunset, as the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, ruled that his Hajj was complete and his duties fulfilled. The majority answered that 'standing during the day' in the Hadith means standing until sunset; due to the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and the Rightly Guided Caliphs, as they did not depart until after sunset. If one departs before sunset, his Hajj is valid according to Urwa's Hadith, but blood is obligatory upon him due to the report of Ibn Abbas. Al-Shanqiti says: 'His saying, peace and blessings be upon him: 'then his Hajj is complete' arranged with 'Fa' (then) upon his standing at Arafat by night or day, indicates that the one standing during the day completes his Hajj by that. The expression using the word 'complete' (Tam) is apparent in the lack of necessity for compensation by blood. No explicit text has been established contradicting the apparent meaning of this Hadith. The lack of necessity for blood for the one who limits himself to the day is the correct view in the Shafi'i school, due to the indication of this Hadith for that as you see, and knowledge is with Allah (1).

text: Second: No evidence has been established necessitating standing until sunset, and the evidences mentioned by the majority are not accepted for deduction, either due to generality of indication or lack of authenticity. Third: The original state is freedom from liability (Bara'at al-Dhimmah), and there is no text transferring from this original state, so it remains. Fourth: The possibility of reconciling the Hadiths by interpreting what appears to be a command as recommendation; because a command indicates obligation and recommendation, and implies obligation only when absolute and without opposing evidence, which is not the case here. Fifth: The hardship involved in the opinion of obligation, especially with severe overcrowding and frequent accidents, and hardship brings facilitation. Add to that the issue is one of Ijtihad, and there is nothing in the texts supporting the view of obligation, so it remains on recommendation due to the removal of harm and lifting of difficulty it contains. If it is said: This hardship existed during the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, yet he did not depart before sunset, indicating obligation. The answer: The hardship in his time, peace and blessings be upon him, was easier than the hardship present in Hajj in later eras, especially with the existence of the Hadith of Urwa bin Mudarris and Abd al-Rahman Al-Dili.

text: Sixth: If standing at night is permitted without blood penalty by consensus of scholars; then standing during the day without the night is permitted a fortiori. Whoever differentiates between night and day has differentiated between two likes, which the aforementioned Hadith of Urwa equated. The preferred view, looking at the evidences, is the obligation of standing at Arafat until sunset; because it is established from the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, his command to his Ummah to take the rites from him, and his command to oppose the polytheists, and opposing the polytheists is an objective of the Sharia. The Hadith of Urwa is specific to those in a similar condition to him, for the narrations mention his saying: 'I exhausted my mount and tired myself, I did not leave any hill except that I stood upon it.' So the fatwa came considering the state of the questioner by saying: 'and came to Arafat before that by night or day, then his Hajj is complete, and he has completed his prescribed duties.' Otherwise, the one who says departing before sunset is permissible relying on Urwa's Hadith would have to permit the distressed and others to stand at any hour of day or night. Despite this, if a man departs before sunset due to ignorance, forgetfulness, or necessity, there is no blood penalty upon him according to the preferred view; because his condition is like that of Urwa, and the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not obligate him with blood. It is known that Qiyas (analogy) is attaching a branch to a root in ruling due to their unity in the effective cause (Illah).

text: Issue Two: Tawaf al-Ifadah: The second pillar is Tawaf al-Ifadah, also called Tawaf al-Hajj and Al-Ziyarah. It can only be done after standing at Arafat and spending the night at Muzdalifah without disagreement among scholars (1). This is the apparent meaning of the Holy Quran, due to His saying, Glory be to Him: {Then let them end their untidiness and fulfill their vows and perform Tawaf around the ancient House} [Al-Hajj: 29], making Tawaf the last of them (2). Among the manifestations of facilitation in Tawaf al-Ifadah: 1. The time for Tawaf begins after midnight (the night of Muzdalifah) for those permitted to depart from it among the weak, women, and those in their ruling. Does it begin after Fajr or after midnight? There are two opinions among scholars, and the matter is broad due to the lack of text on this issue. 2. The 'Four Schools' agreed (3) that Tawaf al-Ifadah suffices

text: at any time from the dawn of the Day of Sacrifice until the end of the days of Dhu al-Hijjah, and even if done after the month, it suffices. 3. He may delay Tawaf al-Ifadah to combine with the Farewell (Wada') (1), making it one Tawaf to alleviate hardship on himself and overcrowding on his brothers. Al-Nawawi said: 'Al-Shafi'i said in Al-Umm, and Sheikh Abu Hamid, Qadi Abu al-Tayyib, and all the companions said: Whenever Tawaf al-Ifadah is upon him, and he intends another for himself, or for another voluntarily, or for farewell, it counts as Tawaf al-Ifadah. Just as if he entered Ihram for voluntary Hajj or Umrah while owing their obligation, the obligation is convened' (2). You notice from Al-Nawawi's text that if the pilgrim forgets Ifadah and performs Tawaf for Farewell without intending Ifadah, or out of ignorance of the obligation of Tawaf, his Tawaf suffices for both. This is a good aspect, and part of facilitation and concession. 4. Is purity (Taharah) a condition for Tawaf? Scholars differed on this issue with two opinions: The First Opinion: They stipulated purity from [minor] ritual impurity and filth. This is the view of

Accordingly, the menstruating and postpartum woman must remain until she becomes pure. They used the following as evidence: 1. What Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) reported from the Hadith of Aisha: The first thing the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, started with when he arrived was that he performed ablution, then circumambulated the House. If it is said: His ablution, peace and blessings be upon him, mentioned in Aisha's Hadith is an absolute action, and it does not indicate obligation, let alone being a condition for Tawaf. The Answer: His ablution for his mentioned Tawaf is indicated by two proofs to be necessary and indispensable: First: That he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: 'Take your rites from me.' This command implies obligation and necessity. Since he performed ablution for Tawaf, we are obliged to take it from him; in compliance with his command, peace and blessings be upon him. Second: It has been established in the principles (Usul) that the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, if it is

Tawaf around the House differs from prayer in many things other than speech, including: standing is not a condition for it, nor Takbir, and eating and drinking and other things are permitted in it. 4. As for his companions, they differ on the obligation of purity for Tawaf while agreeing that it is not a condition for it (2). Accordingly, the Tawaf of the impure person, such as the menstruating woman, the postpartum woman, and the Junub, is valid, but blood penalty (Dam) is required for it. Imam Ahmad (3) went in a narration from him to the view that purity is not a condition, and Sheikh al-Islam chose this (4). They used the following as evidence: 1. The point of evidence is that Allah commanded Tawaf absolutely, and did not restrict it with the condition of purity, and this is a definitive text. 2. That the original state is freedom from liability. 3. That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, did not obligate purity upon those circumambulating, nor avoidance of

What Sa'id bin Mansur reported via Ata who said: A woman menstruated while she was circumambulating with Aisha, the Mother of Believers, so Aisha completed the rest of her Tawaf with her (1). Sheikh Muhammad bin Uthaymeen, may Allah have mercy on him, says: 'Accordingly, the preferred view which the soul is reassured by is that purity from minor ritual impurity is not a condition in Tawaf. However, it is undoubtedly better and more complete; following the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. A person should not neglect it to oppose the majority of scholars in that. But sometimes a person is compelled to the view held by Sheikh al-Islam, such as: if he breaks wind during his Tawaf in severe crowding. To say that he must go and perform ablution, then come back into this severe crowding, especially if only part of a round remains for him, implies severe hardship. Whatever involves severe hardship, and the text does not appear clearly regarding it, people should not be bound by it. Rather, we follow what is easier and simpler; because binding people to what involves hardship without clear evidence contradicts His saying: {Allah intends for you ease and does not intend for you hardship} [Al-Baqarah: 185].

text: If you ask: What is the preferred view regarding the Tawaf of a menstruating woman who fears missing her group? Ibn al-Qayyim, may Allah have mercy on him, says: 'The Sixth Example: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, forbade the menstruating woman from circumambulating the House until she is pure, and said: 'Do what the pilgrim does except do not circumambulate the House' (1). Some thought this is a general ruling in all conditions and times, and did not differentiate between the state of ability and inability, nor between the time when remaining is possible for her until she becomes pure and circumambulates, and the time when that is not possible. They held to the apparent meaning of the text, and saw menstruation as incompatible with Tawaf just as it is incompatible with prayer and fasting, since the menstruating woman is forbidden from all equally. [They saw] the incompatibility of menstruation with the worship of Tawaf like its incompatibility with the worship of prayer. Two groups disputed with them on this: One group: Validated Tawaf with menstruation, and did not make menstruation an impediment to its validity. Rather, they made purity obligatory, compensated by blood, and Tawaf is valid without it. This is what Abu Hanifa and his companions say, and Ahmad in one of the two narrations from him, which is the more explicit text from him. These did not make the link of purity to Tawaf like its link to prayer—a link of condition to conditioned—but

book_title: Facilitation for Women in Hajj in the Light of the Prophetic Sunnah
publisher: Dar Al-Hadara for Publishing and Distribution
text: they made it one of its duties, and its link to it like the link of Hajj duties to it; doing it is valid with omission, and blood compensates for it. The Second Group: Made the obligation of purity for Tawaf, and its conditionality, like the status of covering oneself (Satr), and its conditionality is rather like the status of other conditions and duties of prayer which are obligatory and stipulated with ability, and drop with inability. They said: Conditioning purity for Tawaf or its obligation for it is not greater than conditioning it for prayer. So if it drops due to inability in prayer, its dropping in Tawaf due to inability is more appropriate. They said: In the time of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his Rightly Guided Caliphs, Hajj leaders used to be detained for menstruating women until they became pure and performed Tawaf. That is why the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding Safiyyah when she menstruated: 'Is she detaining us?' They said: 'She has performed Ifadah (Tawaf).' He said: 'Then let her depart' (1). At that time, purity was within her ability, she could perform Tawaf with it. As for these times when it is impossible for the rider (traveler) to stay due to menstruation, it does not fall outside of eight categories:

The first: That it is said to her, 'Stay in Mecca, even if the caravan leaves, until you become pure and perform Tawaf.' In this, there is exposing her to staying alone in a foreign land, along with the extreme harm that entails.
The second: That it is said, 'The Tawaf al-Ifadah is waived due to the inability to fulfill its condition.'
The third: That it is said, 'If she knows or fears the onset of menstruation at its time, it is permissible for her to perform it before its time.'
The fourth: That it is said, 'If she knows by habit that her menses come during the days of Hajj, and that if she performs Hajj she will get her period there, the obligation falls from her until she reaches menopause and her menses stop completely.'
The fifth: That it is said, 'Rather, she performs Hajj, and if she menstruates and cannot perform Tawaf or stay, she returns home. She remains in her state of Ihram, refraining from marriage and intercourse with her husband until she returns to the House and performs Tawaf while pure,' even if there is a distance of years between her and it. Then, if she gets her period in the year of return, she goes back as she is, and continues like this until she encounters a year in which she is pure.
The sixth: That it is said, 'Rather, she decomposes (Tahallul) if she is unable to stay until she becomes pure, just as a besieged person (Muhsar) decomposes, with the Hajj remaining as a debt upon her. So whenever she is able to perform Hajj...

...it becomes binding upon her. Then, if that [menstruation] happens to her again, she decomposes, and so on forever until she can perform Tawaf while pure.'
The seventh: That it is said, 'She must appoint someone to perform Hajj on her behalf.'
The eighth: That it is said, 'Rather, she does what she is capable of from the rituals of Hajj, and whatever conditions and duties she is incapable of are waived for her, just as the Farewell Tawaf (Tawaf al-Wada') is waived for her by text.'
The speech of the Imams and Jurists is general, as they speak regarding its likes. They did not address such specific scenarios which have become a widespread affliction (Umum al-Balwa). This was not the case in the time of the Imams; rather, they mentioned that the camel-renter is obliged to wait for the first period and be detained for her so she can become pure and then perform Tawaf. This was possible, indeed actual, in their time, so they issued fatwas that she does not perform Tawaf until she becomes pure because she was able to do so, and there is no dispute in this. As for these times, it is not possible. Obligating two complete journeys for Hajj without negligence from the pilgrim, nor a cause originating from her, implies obligating two pilgrimages to the House, whereas Allah Almighty only obligated one pilgrimage. This is unlike one who invalidates the Hajj, for he has been negligent by committing a prohibition. And it is unlike one who abandoned the Tawaf of Visitation (Ziyarah) or standing at Arafah, for he did not do what completes his Hajj. As for this woman, she was not negligent and did not abandon what she was commanded to do,

publisher: Dar Al-Hadara for Publishing and Distribution
text: for she was not commanded to do what she is incapable of, and she has done what she is capable of. She is in the position of a person in a state of major impurity (Junub) if he is unable to perform the original purification or the substitute, so he prays according to his condition, and there is no repetition upon him according to the most correct of opinions..." Then he refuted the estimation of the seven mentioned cases, then said: "...So if these estimations are invalid, the eighth estimation becomes determined: which is that it be said she performs Tawaf of the House in this state. This is a necessity requiring entering the Mosque with menstruation and performing Tawaf with it. There is nothing in this that contradicts the rules of the Sharia; rather, it agrees with them as mentioned, since its ultimate result is the dropping of a duty or condition due to inability to fulfill it. There is no duty in the Sharia with inability, nor is there a prohibition with necessity." ... And regarding whether a penalty (Dam/Blood) is binding upon her or not, he said: "Our Sheikh said: If she performs Tawaf while menstruating without an excuse, the view that a penalty is obligatory is valid. But with inability, the most likely view is that no penalty is obligated; because purification is a duty commanded with ability, not with inability. The obligation of a penalty is for abandoning a command or committing a prohibition. This woman did not abandon a command in this state, nor did she commit a prohibition. For if she threw the Jamrah and shortened her hair, everything prohibited to her by Ihram becomes lawful except marriage. Thus, after the first decomposition (Tahallul), no prohibition remains for which doing it requires a penalty. And purification is not commanded with inability such that abandoning it would require a penalty."

text: Then he concluded the issue by saying: "In summary, the speech regarding this incident is in two chapters. First: That the rules of Sharia require it, not contradict it, and this has been clarified sufficiently. Second: That the speech of the Imams and their fatwas regarding conditions and obligations is only in the state of ability and capacity, not in the state of necessity and inability. So issuing a fatwa permitting this does not contradict the text of the Lawgiver, nor the saying of the Imams. The utmost action of the Mufti in this case is restricting the absolute speech of the Lawgiver with the rules and principles of His Sharia, and the absolute speech of the Imams with their rules and principles. Thus, the one issuing a fatwa permitting this is in agreement with the principles of the Sharia and its rules, and with the rules of the Imams" (1). From this, you learn that the preferred view (Rajih) is that if a woman is compelled to perform Tawaf al-Ifadah while in her menses, it is permissible for her, and there is nothing [no penalty] upon her. However, she must guard against what is feared regarding soiling the Mosque, by binding herself tightly. But if she is capable of performing Tawaf after becoming pure, the Imams are agreed that she does not perform Tawaf until she is pure.

The Second Requirement: Facilitation in the Duties of Hajj
It contains several issues:
The First Issue: You may have noticed, O noble reader, during the research, Islam's constant eagerness to lighten the burden on women in many rulings, considering in that the nature of her creation and the weakness and femininity she was formed with, which prepares her to perform her function in life connected to her home and residence. We also note Islam's eagerness to protect the woman and keep her away from crowding with men. From this premise, do not be surprised when you do not find disagreement that a woman may hasten and depart from Muzdalifah after the moon sets. It is not a condition that she be sick; rather, she has that right even if she has no ailment, so that she can proceed to Mina and throw the Jamrah without crowding with men (1). The scholars have evidences from the Prophetic Sunnah, including:

1. Facilitation in the time of stoning Jamrat al-Aqabah:
The scholars differed regarding the time in which it is permissible to stone Jamrat al-Aqabah for the weak and others—while agreeing that whoever throws after sunrise, it suffices him—into three opinions:
The First Opinion: The opinion of Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, and a group of scholars (1). They said: The first time in which stoning Jamrat al-Aqabah suffices is the beginning of the second half of the night of Nahr (Sacrifice) for both the capable and the incapable.
They used as evidence what Abu Dawood (2) narrated from Aisha (may Allah be pleased with her) that she said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, sent Umm Salamah on the night of Nahr, so she threw the Jamrah before Fajr, then went on and performed Tawaf al-Ifadah. That was the day the Messenger of Allah was to be with her.
Imam Ahmad rejected this (3), and Al-Albani classified it as weak in Al-Irwa. Also, since it is a time for departing from Muzdalifah, it is likewise a time for Stoning.

Their argument is that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, threw it at Duha (forenoon) time and said: "Take your rituals from me." They also argued with what the Four (2) narrated from the hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: "The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, used to send the weak of his family ahead in the darkness (Ghalas), and command them not to throw the Jamrah until the sun rose." The wording is Abu Dawood's. Al-Tirmidhi said: Hasan Sahih. The practice is according to this hadith among the people of knowledge. Al-Nawawi, Ibn al-Qayyim, and Al-Albani declared it authentic (3).
The Third Opinion: What some scholars went to, and chosen by Ibn al-Qayyim (4). They said: Its first time for the weak is from the break of dawn (Fajr), and for others, it is after sunrise. They used two hadiths as evidence for this:

The First: The agreed-upon hadith of Asma (1), wherein it says "So we departed and went on until she threw the Jamrah, then she returned and prayed Fajr in her residence," and wherein she said: "O my son, indeed the Messenger of Allah gave permission to the Za'n." Its implication is that he did not give permission to the strong males.
The Second: What Al-Bukhari and Muslim (2) narrated from the hadith of Salim who said: Abdullah bin Umar used to send the weak of his family ahead, so they would stand at the Sacred Monument (Al-Mash'ar Al-Haram) at Muzdalifah at night, mentioning Allah as much as they could. Then they would return before the Imam stood and before he departed. Some of them would arrive at Mina for Fajr prayer, and some would arrive after that. When they arrived, they would throw the Jamrah. Ibn Umar used to say: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, granted a concession to those. This indicates permitting the weak to throw Jamrat al-Aqabah after Fajr, but he did not permit others.
The preferred view (Rajih) upon examining the evidence is the permissibility of throwing for the weak and the strong who arrive with them, due to the hadith of Aisha, and because the weak need someone to accompany them for the rest of the Hajj rituals. Unless we take the concessions, especially with the great crowding...

2. Facilitation in the time of Stoning (General):
• It is permissible for the pilgrim to throw at night: This is the saying of Ibn Umar, and the Hanafis went to it, as well as Malik, and one of the two sayings of the Shafi'is. The Constituent Council of the Muslim World League, headed by Sheikh Abdul Aziz bin Baz (may Allah have mercy on him), issued a fatwa for this when the crowding at the Jamarat became severe (2).
They used as evidence:
1. What Al-Bukhari narrated (3) from Ibn Abbas who said: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was asked: "I threw after evening came?" He said: "No harm." [Another] said: "I shaved before I sacrificed?" He said: "No harm." The name "evening" (Masa') applies to part of the night.

So she and Safiyyah stayed behind until they arrived at Mina after the sun had set on the Day of Nahr. Abdullah bin Umar ordered them to throw, and he did not see anything [penalty] upon them. This is evidence from the action of Ibn Umar (may Allah be pleased with him) that throwing at night is permissible.
• It is permissible for the pilgrim to throw before Zawal (noon/zenith) on all days: This is reported from Ibn Abbas, and is the saying of Tawus, and Ataa in one of the two narrations from him, and Muhammad al-Baqir. It is a non-famous narration among the Hanafis: Throwing before Zawal is permissible on the third day absolutely, and on the second day for the one hastening (Muta'ajjil). Its chain is weak. Ibn Qudamah said in 'Al-Kafi': "Everyone with an excuse of illness or fear for himself or his wealth is like the shepherds in this; because they are in their meaning [condition]" (2).
2. What Al-Bukhari and Muslim narrated from the hadith of Abdullah bin Amr bin Al-Aas that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, stood at Mina during the Farewell Pilgrimage for the people asking him. A man came and said: "I didn't realize, so I shaved before I sacrificed?" He said: "Sacrifice and no harm." Another came and said: "I didn't realize, so I sacrificed before I threw?" He said: "Throw and no harm." The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, was not asked about anything done before or after [its order] except that he said: "Do it and no harm." The point of evidence is that the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, did not make the order between Hajj duties a condition, and in this is an indication of not strictly observing the time.

4. As for the Messenger of Allah throwing after Zawal, it is like his standing at Arafah after Zawal until sunset. It is known that standing does not end with that limit; rather, the entire night is also a time for standing.
5. If throwing before Zawal were prohibited, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, would have clarified it with a sufficient, explicit clarification when he answered the questioner who asked about throwing after evening. Delaying clarification past the time of need is not permissible.
6. From the evidences is His Almighty's saying: {And remember Allah during [specific] numbered days} [Al-Baqarah: 203]. Stoning is part of Remembrance, based on what Abu Dawood narrated (1) from the hadith of Aisha (Marfu'): "Indeed, circumambulating the House, [going] between Safa and Marwa, and stoning the Jamarat were ordained for establishing the remembrance of Allah." Al-Albani weakened it (2). So He made the entire day a place for remembrance, and Stoning is part of it. Upon contemplation, this appears to be like a textual proof in the issue, and Sheikh Abdul Rahman bin Sa'di used it as evidence.

He said: We used to wait for the time, so when the sun passed its zenith (Zalat), we threw. If throwing before Zawal were obligatory [prohibited], he would have clarified it to the questioner initially.
8. That stoning Jamrat al-Aqabah was advanced from sunrise to before Fajr in consideration of facilitation and kindness to the weak, even though spending the night in Mina is incumbent upon pilgrims during the days of Tashreeq. So how about the one hastening on the twelfth day? Adopting this opinion contains a concession for women and the weak, especially on the twelfth day for those hastening.
• He may delay throwing the Jamarat, except for the day of Eid, to the last day; because the days of Tashreeq are like a single day. Thus, throwing in all of them is performance (Ada'). So if he throws for the first day on the second, or for the second on the third, or for the first and second on the third, there is nothing [penalty] upon him; because it is a time for throwing, like a single day. However, he misses the Sunnah by doing so. This was said by Al-Shafi'i, Ahmad, Abu Thaur, Abu Yusuf, and Muhammad. Al-Shanqeeti chose this opinion (2).

They used as evidence what the Four (1) narrated from the hadith of Asim bin Adi: "That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, granted a concession to the shepherds regarding spending the night [in Mina], that they throw on the Day of Nahr, and for the two days after it, they combine them in one of them." The wording is Al-Nasa'i's. According to Abu Dawood, Al-Nasa'i, and Ibn Majah: "He granted a concession to the shepherds to throw one day and leave one day." Al-Tirmidhi said: A Hasan Sahih hadith, and Al-Albani authenticated it in Al-Irwa (2).
So it is permissible for one who is in the meaning/condition of shepherds—those occupied during the days of throwing with work that leaves no time for throwing, and whose residence is far from the Jamarat, and for whom visiting them repeatedly is difficult, especially women—to delay throwing the Jamarat until the last day of the days of Tashreeq, but not delay it beyond that.
Ibn Qudamah says: "People with excuses other than shepherds, such as the sick, and those who have wealth they fear losing, and the like, are like shepherds in omitting the overnight stay; because the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, granted a concession to these as an alert for others. Or you say: The meaning stipulated for them exists in others, so it is obligatory to append them to them" (3).

Delaying to avoid crowding, hardship, and fighting is one of the greatest considered objectives. Human life is more worthy of care than the life of livestock as in the case of shepherds. Preserving souls is one of the five objectives agreed upon in the Sharia.
3. Facilitation regarding Deputyship (Proxy) in Stoning:
Whoever is unable to throw by himself due to illness or the like, permitted for him to appoint someone to throw on his behalf. There is nothing [no penalty] upon him according to the Hanafis, Shafi'is, and Hanbalis (1), with a difference among them regarding repeating the throw if his inability ceases before the last of the days of Tashreeq.
As for Imam Malik, he was asked: Does one throw on behalf of a child and a sick person? He said: Yes, and the sick person should seek the time when he throws for him, so he says Takbir while in his residence, and he must shed blood (sacrifice) (2). So he permitted deputyship with inability but obligated the incapable person to sacrifice.
In Al-Mughni: "Ibn al-Mundhir said: Everyone I have memorized from among the people of knowledge sees [permissibility of] throwing on behalf of the child who cannot throw. Ibn Umar used to do that, and Ataa, Al-Zuhri, Malik, Al-Shafi'i, and Ishaq said so" (3).

Abu Ishaq al-Shirazi said: "Whoever is unable to throw by himself, whether the illness is hopeless or not, it is permissible for him to appoint someone to throw for him; because its time is tight and might pass before he can throw..." (1).
Ibn Qudamah said: "If a man is sick, or [a woman] is detained/imprisoned, and has an excuse, it is permissible to appoint someone to throw on his/her behalf" (2).
From this, it becomes clear to you that the criterion for deputyship is the excuse that renders its owner incapable of throwing, such as illness, youth, imprisonment, weakness, and others. It is not permissible to appoint a proxy for throwing without an excuse; whoever does so sins and owes a sacrifice.
They used as evidence:
1. What Ibn Abi Shaybah narrated in Al-Musannaf (3), and Ibn Majah in Al-Sunan (4) from the hadith of Jabir who said: "We performed Hajj with the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and with us were women and children. So we said Talbiyah on behalf of the children, and we threw on their behalf." Its chain is weak due to the weakness of Ash'ath bin Yasar and the 'an'anah (transmission using 'from') of Abu al-Zubayr.

2. Deputyship in throwing is the utmost that the incapable person can do, and Allah Almighty says: {So fear Allah as much as you are able} [At-Taghabun: 16].
3. Analogy of deputyship in throwing to deputyship in the Hajj itself. They said: Throwing is more deserving of permissibility.
4. Among the evidence of the majority for the dropping of the sacrifice from the incapable person who appoints another is what the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, dropped from the incapable regarding duties, such as the Farewell Tawaf for the menstruating woman, and the overnight stay for shepherds. He did not mandate a sacrifice, and it is known that delaying clarification past the time of need is not permissible.
The Third Issue: Dropping of Farewell Tawaf (Tawaf al-Wada') for the Menstruating Woman and Woman with Postnatal Bleeding:
Farewell Tawaf is obligatory, and abandoning it requires a sacrifice. This is the saying of the majority of scholars, and the Hanafis, a narration from the Shafi'is, and the Hanbalis went to it (2).

Is the Farewell Tawaf obligatory on the menstruating woman and the one with postnatal bleeding? Does it drop? And if it drops, is it compensated by a sacrifice or not?
Ibn al-Mundhir said: "The general body of jurists in the regions said: There is no Farewell Tawaf upon the menstruating woman who has already performed Tawaf al-Ifadah" (1).
Ibn Qudamah said: "If a woman menstruates before she bids farewell, she departs, and there is no farewell [Tawaf] upon her nor a ransom (Fidyah). This is the saying of the general jurists of the regions. It was narrated from Umar and his son that they ordered the menstruating woman to stay for the Farewell Tawaf, and Zaid bin Thabit used to say that, but he retracted it" (2).
The authentic, explicit evidences for the majority opinion are many, including:
1. What Al-Bukhari and Muslim (3) narrated from the hadith of Ibn Abbas who said: The people were commanded that their last time be at the House, except that it was lightened for the menstruating woman.
2. What Al-Bukhari and Muslim (4) narrated from the hadith of Aisha who said: Safiyyah bint Huyayy menstruated after she had performed Ifadah. Aisha said:

Conclusion
Praise be to Allah by Whose grace good deeds are completed. Praise be to Allah who legislated the easiest of religion and the most complete of creeds. Prayers and peace be upon the Imam of the pure monotheists, whom his Lord sent as a facilitator and bringer of glad tidings. To proceed:
Indeed, this research has only touched upon a very small amount of the manifestations of facilitation regarding the jurisprudence of women. These pages are but drops from a sea and grains from a basket. In the authentic Sunnah, thousands of pages would fail to highlight its tolerance regarding Hajj. But it is the effort of one with little, asking Allah to accept it.
Along with the manifestations of facilitation that appeared clearly regarding women and those in their ruling in the obligation of Hajj—to lift physical hardship—there are great matters through which Islam's care for intangibles appears, and its satisfaction of the soul's needs before the body. This is seen through the dealing of the great Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, personally with his nine wives who performed Hajj with him. There is no doubt in the wisdom of his actions and his virtuous character; for he understands the nature of woman, her flowing emotion, and her being the dwelling of the parent and the incubator of the child. How [could he not], when he likened women to glass vessels (Qawarir) in delicacy, gentleness, and weakness of constitution? Thus, the rulings of the spirit and body came in a way...
